title: Sans serif to accompany Cremona?
content:
I’ve inherited a logo that uses Cremona, and am looking for a compatible sans serif. Any suggestions?

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/cremona-bq/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203112045/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/cremona-bq/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/cremona-bq/")

 [‹ Advice for magazine fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203112045/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38943 "Go to previous forum topic") [Days of Thunder match ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203112045/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38906 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Pat Thompson

comments.content: What kind of a company does the inherited logo belong?
It’s a foundation that is the charitable wing of an association of credit unions. So officially, it’s connected with banking, but it’s also a nonprofit.

Perhaps the still-under-development Sugar Sans? Look if I was funny I’d be posting on Comedy Central’s board.

Seriously, however, call me crazy but I think either the book weight of “National” here:  
 [http://www.vllg.com/KLIM/National/mudTyper+Weights/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203112045/http:/www.vllg.com/KLIM/National/mudTyper+Weights/ "http://www.vllg.com/KLIM/National/mudTyper+Weights/")

Or Stella Regular here:  
 [http://www.vllg.com/Feliciano/Stella/mudTyper+Weights/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203112045/http:/www.vllg.com/Feliciano/Stella/mudTyper+Weights/ "http://www.vllg.com/Feliciano/Stella/mudTyper+Weights/")

would be a solid choice still far enough off the beaten path to make you appear particularly resourceful and meticulous.

Of course then there’s always Switzerland Narrow.
